Award.AwardTitle: Identity, function, and transport of lignocellulose-active enzymes in wood-eating (xylotrophic) bivalves (shipworms)
Award.AbstractNarration: Shipworms are worm-like marine clams that burrow in wood, using wood for both food and shelter. Because few animals eat wood, there is great interest in those that can. Previous research in this investigator's laboratory suggested that shipworms digest wood using a method that is different from any other animal. Most animals that eat wood, e.g. termites or wood-eating roaches, do so with the help of enzymes made by bacteria and other microbes that live in their digestive systems. Shipworms, however, have few bacteria in their digestive systems. Instead, they rely on bacterial symbionts that live inside the cells of their gills to produce the digestive enzymes they need. This is unique because no other known animal relies on intracellular symbionts to produce digestive enzymes. In this project, the enzymes produced by these bacteria will be identified in order to characterize their functions, and to determine how these enzymes are transported from inside the cells of the shipworm's gills to their digestive system. These enzymes are potentially valuable because they convert wood, the most abundant biomaterial on earth, into soluble sugars that can be fermented into renewable biofuels, e.g. ethanol. They may also be used in production or processing of paper, textiles, detergents, food, animal feed and waste materials. This project will contribute to Ocean Genome Legacy's ongoing postdoctoral training and graduate education programs, public outreach for environmental literacy, and internship programs for undergraduate, high school, and minority students. The investigators will also work with colleagues in the Pacific Northwest to develop a STEM education program for Native Alaskan students and teachers that integrates shipworm biology with traditional Native Alaskan ecological knowledge and Western science; this program will utilize educational curricula translated into the Haida language.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research summary: Few animals are able to eat wood (lignocellulose). In the terrestrial world the primary consumers of wood are termites. In the oceans a group of bivalves called shipworms assumes this role. In our research we aimed to discover the mechanisms by which shipworms digest wood. In this work we showed that shipworms digest wood using a mechanism much different than any other animal. Rather than maintaining a complex community of gut bacteria that help make the enzymes needed to digest wood, as termites do, the part of the digestive system in which shipworms digest wood is largely devoid of bacteria. Instead, shipworms maintain a community of symbiotic bacteria in their gills, an organ that is not normally part of the digestive system. Using modern techniques of genomics and proteomics, we showed that wood-digesting enzymes found in the gut of the shipworm Bankia setacea are encoded in the genes of the gill bacteria. This demonstrated that the gill symbionts produce the wood degrading  enzymes found in the shipworm’s gut. We also demonstrated that these wood digesting enzymes are selectively transported from the gill to the gut, to the exclusion of other proteins made by the symbionts in the gills. Finally, we developed methods to grow these bacteria in pure culture outside of the host, making it possible to produce and study these enzymes in large quantities.  This ability will make it much easier to explore the potential practical applications of the enzymes used in the shipworm digestive system. 

Intellectual merit:  As the most abundant biopolymer on earth, lignocellulose is among the most important carbon sinks, most commonly used structural materials, and most abundant contributors to landfill waste.  It is also a potential source of renewable energy and fine chemicals. As such, there is great ecological, technological and economic value in understanding its decomposition. Shipworms, the principle degraders of lignocellulose in many marine waters, are both costly pests and beneficial organisms. Shipworms cause an estimated $1B annually in damage to wooden boats, piers and fishing equipment, but also clear hazardous woody debris from navigable waters and convert woody material to readily digestible biomass. The simplicity and novelty of their symbiotic communities and unique nature of their digestive mechanism make the shipworm symbiosis a tractable and informative counterpoint to better known wood-eating symbioses (e.g. termites) and a source of valuable candidate enzymes for practical technical applications, including production or processing of biofuel, paper, textiles, detergents, food, animal feed and waste materials.  

Broader significance:This project contributed to postdoctoral training and education programs, public outreach for environmental literacy, internship programs for undergraduate, high school, and minority students and aSTEM education program for Native Alaskan students and teachers that integrates shipworm biology, traditional ecological knowledge and Western science and that utilizes educational curricula translated into the Haida language.
